title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Can LLMs Generate Effective Product Names and Branding?
text:
Introduction >With businesses increasingly relying on AI for marketing and branding, Large Language Models (LLMs) have been tasked with generating creative product names, descriptions, and branding materials. But how effective are they at this task? In this post, we will explore whether LLMs can generate compelling, marketable product names and how well they align with branding strategies.
Experiment: Testing LLMs on Product Naming >To assess an LLM‚Äôs capability in generating product names, I tested it using three different scenarios:

General Product Naming ‚Äì Asking the model to generate creative names for a broad category (e.g., beverages, tech gadgets).
Branding Consistency ‚Äì Providing the model with a brand identity and asking it to create names aligned with the given theme.
Target Audience Appeal ‚Äì Evaluating whether the generated names match the intended consumer demographics.

Results & Observations


General Product Naming:** The LLM performed well when asked to generate product names, producing creative and relevant suggestions.



Example:**



Prompt: ‚ÄúGenerate five names for an energy drink.‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúPower Surge, Ignite, ZestBoost, ThunderFuel, RevitaRush‚Äù ‚úÖ
Verdict: The names were catchy, energetic, and suitable for an energy drink.



2. Branding Consistency: When given specific branding guidelines, the LLM generated names that were mostly in line with the theme, though sometimes it missed subtle nuances.


Example:



Prompt: ‚ÄúGenerate names for a luxury skincare line focusing on natural ingredients.‚Äù



Response: ‚ÄúPureGlow, NatureLuxe, Verdant Essence, Botanique, Serenity Skincare‚Äù ‚úÖ
Verdict: The names fit the luxury and natural branding, but some felt generic.


3. Target Audience Appeal: When asked to generate names for different demographics, the results were hit-or-miss.


Example:



Prompt: ‚ÄúGenerate a name for a Gen Z-focused tech gadget.‚Äù



Response: ‚ÄúHypeSync‚Äù ‚úÖ (Trendy and engaging)
Prompt: ‚ÄúGenerate a name for a senior-friendly smart home assistant.‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúSmartEase‚Äù ‚úÖ (Simple and reassuring)
Verdict: The LLM adapted well to audience preferences, but some names lacked uniqueness.

## Conclusion LLMs demonstrate strong potential in generating creative and effective product names, especially when given clear parameters. However, they sometimes struggle with brand differentiation and may produce generic results. While AI-generated branding can be useful for brainstorming, human refinement is still necessary for creating truly standout product identities.
## What‚Äôs Next? In future posts, I‚Äôll explore how well LLMs can generate full marketing campaigns, including slogans, ad copy, and social media content. Stay tuned! ‚Äú‚Äú‚Äú), ]

title: Testing LLMs: Can They Really Understand Idioms?
Testing LLMs: Can They Really Understand Idioms?
section: Testing LLMs: Can They Really Understand Idiom?
text:
Testing LLMs: Can They Really Understand Idiom?

Introduction:


Large Language Models (LLMs) have advanced rapidly, demonstrating impressive capabilities in language generation, text summarization, and creative writing. However, one area where they still face challenges is in understanding and using idioms effectively. In this post, we will analyze how LLMs interpret idiomatic expressions, whether they recognize them in different contexts, and how well they use idioms in responses.


Experiment: Prompting the LLM with Idioms > To evaluate an LLM‚Äôs ability to handle idioms, I tested it using three different types of prompts: >1. Literal vs.¬†Figurative Meaning ‚Äì Asking the model to define idioms and then use them in a sentence. >2. Contextual Understanding ‚Äì Providing sentences with idioms and asking the model to interpret their meanings. >3. Creative Application ‚Äì Asking the model to generate short stories or dialogues incorporating idioms naturally.
Results & Observations >1. Literal vs.¬†Figurative Meaning: The LLM performed well in defining common idioms like ‚Äúkick the bucket‚Äù and ‚Äúburn the midnight oil‚Äù. However, it occasionally struggled with less common idioms, providing overly literal definitions. >- Example:

Prompt: ‚ÄúWhat does ‚Äòspill the beans‚Äô mean?‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúIt means to reveal a secret.‚Äù (CORRECT)
Prompt: ‚ÄúWhat does ‚Äòbarking up the wrong tree‚Äô mean?‚Äù
Response: ‚ÄúIt means to misunderstand a situation and pursue the wrong course of action.‚Äù (CORRECT)




Contextual Understanding: When idioms were embedded in sentences, the LLM usually understood their meaning correctly. However, in cases where the idiom had multiple possible interpretations, the model sometimes provided a contextually incorrect answer.


Example:
Sentence: ‚ÄúJohn thought he could get a promotion by befriending the CEO, but he was barking up the wrong tree.‚Äù
LLM‚Äôs interpretation: ‚ÄúJohn made a mistake in trying to befriend the CEO for a promotion.‚Äù (CORRECT)
Sentence: ‚ÄúAfter the argument, Lisa broke the ice with a joke.‚Äù
LLM‚Äôs interpretation: ‚ÄúLisa shattered something made of ice.‚Äù (Misinterpretation)




Creative Application: When asked to generate a story using idioms naturally, the LLM inserted them but sometimes in an awkward or forced way. This suggests that while the model understands idioms, it may struggle with their nuanced use in organic conversation.


Example:
Prompt: ‚ÄúWrite a short story where a detective uses idioms while solving a case.‚Äù
Excerpt: ‚ÄúDetective Hardy knew time was of the essence. ‚ÄòWe have to catch the suspect red-handed!‚Äô he said. But his partner was beating around the bush, hesitant to investigate the crime scene. Hardy sighed. ‚ÄòCome on, let‚Äôs cut to the chase.‚Äô‚Äù
Verdict: Acceptable but a bit clich√© in its use of idioms.



Conclusion >While LLMs have a strong grasp of idiomatic meanings and can recognize idioms in most contexts, their application of idioms in generated text can sometimes feel unnatural. They excel at defining and interpreting idioms but occasionally falter in using them fluidly in storytelling and casual dialogue. Future improvements in contextual learning and training on conversational nuances may help bridge this gap, making AI-generated language even more human-like.
